headline: ODOT: please slow down in work zones
sentences: “This is when we show an extra level of support for those who maintain the highways, who work alongside their coworkers performing needed work under significant risk, and who truly serve the public through their jobs,” Pat McColley, ODOT District 2 deputy director said.

The lives of our men and women depend on it.”
Here are more work zone statistics:
In 2021, the Ohio State Highway Patrol issued 6,015 citations in work zones with 41% being more than 20 mph over the posted speed limit.

“We emphasize repeatedly to our employees to work safely every day, to be on watch for each other, and to keep our work zones safe for motorists passing through,” Chris Hughes, ODOT District 1 deputy director said.

VW independent staff and submitted information
BOWLING GREEN — An important week for the Ohio Department of Transportation (ODOT) is National Work Zone Awareness Week, which runs all this week.
In 2020, 117 of the 857 fatalities were work zone workers, making it all the more important for drivers to slow down and stay focused while approaching and passing through a roadway work zone.
National Work Zone Awareness Week first launched in 1997 as a public awareness campaign to help everyone understand they play a role in keeping motorists and roadway workers safe.

Drivers can protect themselves and our workers simply by slowing down.”
Last year, there were 4,796 crashes in Ohio work zones, 35 percent of them occurred with workers present.
“The men and women who work hard each day to ensure that we have safe roads and bridges in good condition deserve to make it home safely to their family at the end of the day.

This year’s theme is “Work Zones are a Sign to Slow Down.”
“Driving in a work zone requires your undivided attention,” Governor Mike DeWine said.
There have been 162 ODOT workers killed on the job, the last being John Pasko who was hit on I-680 in Mahoning County on March 15, 2018.
“We rely on those we share the road with to drive as safely as possible all the time, but especially through work zones,” he said.
“Speed and distracted driving are two of the biggest issues we see in our work zones,” ODOT Director Jack Marchbanks said.

What many fail to recognize is the vast majority of people killed in work zone crashes are motorists and their passengers.
Locally, ODOT crews in northwest Ohio were struck nine times in 2021 while performing work related to highway maintenance.
Ohio law requires you to move over a lane for any roadside worker or vehicle with flashing lights.
ODOT workers, vehicles, and equipment were hit 154 times last year, resulting in five injuries.
Move over, slow down, and above all pay attention when you’re on the road.
Nationally, work zone deaths have risen for five of the past six years.
“Ask any ODOT worker and they likely have a ‘close call’ story to tell.
Already this year, ODOT crews have been hit more than 70 times.
If you cannot safely move over, you’re required to slow down.
These crashes resulted in 1,759 injuries and 29 deaths.
Of those, 20 workers were injured and one was killed.
That’s unacceptable.
